abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Marfan syndrome (MFS) is a connective tissue disease caused by variants in the <jats:italic>FBN1</jats:italic> gene. Nevertheless, other genes influence the manifestations of the disease, characterized by high clinical variability even within families. We mapped modifier loci for cardiovascular and skeletal manifestations in the mg∆<jats:sup>loxPneo</jats:sup> mouse model for MFS and the synthenic loci in the human genome. Corroborating our findings, one of those loci was identified also as a modifier locus in MFS patients. Here, we investigate the <jats:italic>HSPG2</jats:italic> gene, located in this region, as a candidate modifier gene for MFS. We show a correlation between <jats:italic>Fbn1</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>Hspg2</jats:italic> expression in spinal column and aorta in non-isogenic mg∆<jats:sup>loxPneo</jats:sup> mice. Moreover, we show that mice with severe phenotypes present lower expression of <jats:italic>Hspg2</jats:italic> than those mildly affected. Thus, we propose that <jats:italic>HSPG2</jats:italic> is a strong candidate modifier gene for MFS and its role in modulating disease severity should be investigated in patients.</jats:p>
